case_title: Mst. GHULAM JANAT vs BAHAR SHAH And Other

accussed_details.name: Bahar Shah
accussed_details.designation: Cousin of deceased father of minors
allegation: Irregular appointment as guardian of minors

complaint_summary: Petition challenging the appointment of Bahar Shah as guardian of minors under a compromise deed without proper judicial inquiry into his suitability.
investigation_summary: The Senior Sub-Judge appointed Bahar Shah as guardian based on a compromise deed without assessing his fitness or considering the welfare of the minors as required under the Guardians and Wards Act.
judgment_summary: The High Court dismissed Mst. Janat's petition but exercised suo motu powers under Section 115 of the Civil Procedure Code to set aside the appointment of Bahar Shah as guardian. The Court directed the District Judge to re-evaluate the appointment following proper legal procedures.
Decision_or_verdict: Petition dismissed; order of appointment set aside; fresh proceedings directed.
legal_arguments: Section 47(A) of the Guardians and Wards Act allows appeals to the High Court for guardian appointments.
Section 115 of the Civil Procedure Code permits revisions when no appeal lies.
Under Muhammadan Law, a mother who remarries is disqualified from guardianship of her children from the first marriage.
The welfare of minors must be the overriding consideration in guardian appointments.
key_issues: Irregular appointment of guardian based on compromise deed.
Failure to assess welfare of minors.
Applicability of revisional powers under Section 115 of CPC.

maxims.Interest of minors: The welfare of minors is the paramount consideration in guardianship cases.

legal_terms.Compromise decree: A decree passed based on mutual agreement between parties.
legal_terms.Suo motu: Action taken by a court on its own initiative.

words_and_phrases.Guardianship: Legal responsibility for the care of a minor.
words_and_phrases.Inherent powers: Authority granted to courts to act in the interest of justice.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the appointment of a guardian for minors under the Guardians and Wards Act. The High Court dismissed the petition but intervened suo motu to ensure compliance with legal provisions for the welfare of minors.

arguments.contention: No revision could be entertained under law
support: Section 47(A) of Guardians and Wards Act

high_court_findings.failure_of_lower_court: Senior Sub-Judge failed to determine suitability of guardian and relied solely on compromise.
high_court_findings.special_circumstances: Court ignored imperative provisions of law regarding welfare of minors.

precedents.finding: Compromise without considering welfare of minors is illegal.
Ignoring procedure under Guardians and Wards Act is materially irregular.
Revision may be allowed in exceptional circumstances.

decision.directions: Fresh order for appointment of guardian to be made after complying with provisions of law.
